rename.from: Kymatio Keras Scattering1D example does not work with TF>=2.5
rename.to: Keras Scattering1D example does not work with TF>=2.5

body:
For anyone running into this issue with TF/Keras >=2.5, I made some fixes in a local branch: https://github.com/entn-at/kymatio/tree/fix-dict-wrapper

The changes are essentially to use `str` as keys for `phi_f` and `psi` dicts instead of mixing `int`s and `str`s. Unfortunately, this then breaks torch backend tests (numpy etc. still work). As I currently don't have time to look into this further (and I'm not sure if this will be relevant for future/dev versions), I'll leave this be for now.

issue.title: Fix issue #801 and Merge #775

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body: Somehow sorting the issue for scattering1d by modifying scattering3D backend (ndim resolution) and merge for #775. However, the code runs significantly slower and does not match run times as presented in documented examples.

body:
This is a pretty serious issue and somewhat pops up in #801. We should triage this as high priority. 

To quote my response there; 

"[On my end](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/16qJ0f5-G6_FPKgo99Hf39GrH0QznC3pn?usp=sharing), it seems to pass line 145 (I tested with your J, T, Q, and also with smaller.). Furthermore, like you, I see nothing about an agnostic backend. Perhaps this was added and then removed. Perhaps you were using https://github.com/kymatio/kymatio/pull/738 ?

It does error out with the following when you try summarizing our scattering object...

ValueError: Error processing property 'phi_f' of DictWrapper({0: array(....
And it does appear to make alot of function calls when its running...
[image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39755015/171431232-93d7121d-225c-4ddd-8178-bda940d642e8.png)

Whose our local Keras expert here?:
I did the keras backend but I don't know anything about this software..

@edouardoyallon I'm pro putting up a issue on the tensorflow/keras github, I think this might be a little out of scope for the usual keras users even...

If no one objects, I'll make an issue later tonight or tomorrow morning.

Agree that this is high priority.

> For anyone running into this issue with TF/Keras >=2.5, I made some fixes in a local branch: https://github.com/entn-at/kymatio/tree/fix-dict-wrapper
> 
> The changes are essentially to use `str` as keys for `phi_f` and `psi` dicts instead of mixing `int`s and `str`s. Unfortunately, this then breaks torch backend tests (numpy etc. still work). As I currently don't have time to look into this further (and I'm not sure if this will be relevant for future/dev versions), I'll leave this be for now.

This makes sense. It's not clear why we should be mixing ints and strings as keys here in the first place. Will see if there's a quick fix we can make.

issue.title: Examples are not in CI

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body: Following offline discussion with @lostanlen. Since examples are not tested regularly, they *will* break (see #817, #801, #775) without us realizing it. We should aim to have the examples run at somewhat regularly so we can stay ahead of these things. This will probably include trimming down the examples to a smaller and easier maintainable set.

body:
> . It's not clear why we should be mixing ints and strings as keys here in the first place

Mixing ints and strings is incredibly useful here.
The ints correspond to the "resolutions" at which filters are discretized (i.e., periodized in Fourier). This is not needed at the first layer but speeds up computation a lot at the second layer, because the psi2's operate over a subsampled input.
Same when applying phi's onto a multiresolution U layer to get a single-resolution S layer. 

Meanwhile, the strings are metadata tokens: `xi` (center frequency), `sigma` (bandwidth), and `j` (output resolutions). These tokens are important for padding, sampling, depth first search, precomputing the size, and returning metadata for each scattering path.

I should mention that those "fixes" I made to that branch using `str` as keys isn't really a fix, as the computation becomes incredibly slow (as was already noted in some other issue, I believe). For my personal use, I simply reverted back to TF2.4, but obviously that's not a general solution.

> Mixing ints and strings is incredibly useful here.

I agree that both are needed, but there's probably a more logical structure. A first step would be to put the actual filters in a sub-list (say `psi1_f["filters"][j]` instead of `psi1_f[j]`). This should fix the TF issue without the slowdowns that @entn-at is describing. Really, though, these metadata should probably be stored in a separate dict from the filters.

`"filters"` is not great as a key name. It's really the same filter, just expressed at a different resolution.
Other name ideas:
```python
data
levels
scales
subsamplings
values
```

i like `levels`
